H0.text: Electroluminescence is the process by which a neon light produces visible light.

H1.text: Luminescence is the process by which a neon light produces visible light.

H2.text: Radiation is the process by which a neon light produces visible light.

H3.text: Mitosis is how a neon light produces visible light.

A4.text: Unlike neon and fluorescent lamps, EL lamps are not negative resistance devices so no extra circuitry is needed to regulate the amount of current flowing through them.

A5.text: Electroluminescence is the result of radiative recombination of electrons and holes in a material, usually a semiconductor.

A6.text: When sufficient voltage is applied and sufficient current is supplied between the electrodes, the lamp produces an orange glow discharge.

A7.text: Neon lamps are miniature gas-discharge lamps.

A8.text: Neon lamps are electric signs lighted by long luminous gas-discharge tubes that contain rarefied neon or other gases.

A9.text: When a voltage is applied to electrodes inserted through the glass, an electrical glow discharge results.

A10.text: Discharge in neon emits relatively bright red light; neon-filled switching tubes therefore also act as indicators, shining red when switched on.

A11.text: Neon lamps and neon signage (most of which is not neon based these days) are also low-pressure gas-filled tubes.

A12.text: The principle of the atomic emission spectrum explains the varied colors in neon signs, as well as chemical flame test results.

A14.text: Color Simulation of Element Emission Spectrum Based on NIST data
